{"nick":"joepie91","message":"pcfreak30: in JS specifically, 'classes' are bad because 1) they are not really classes and don't really behave like classes, meaning that it misleads readers as to what the code does, and 2) they limit your flexibility but do not give you any benefits in return","date":"2016-06-25T03:48:00.032Z","type":"message"}

{"nick":"joepie91","message":"it isn't","date":"2016-06-25T03:48:12.417Z","type":"message"}
{"nick":"joepie91","message":"your goal is to specify sub-types, not sub-classes","date":"2016-06-25T03:48:18.526Z","type":"message"}
{"nick":"joepie91","message":"my rewrite accomplishes that same goal and is not any more difficult, complex, or time-consuming","date":"2016-06-25T03:48:36.494Z","type":"message"}
{"nick":"joepie91","message":"it's the same code in a different structure","date":"2016-06-25T03:48:42.351Z","type":"message"}

{"nick":"joepie91","message":"look at createAssignmentTable - it still has the same characteristics of \"specifying a sub-type\" - that is, you specify configuration for that specific type of table","date":"2016-06-25T03:49:28.076Z","type":"message"}
{"nick":"joepie91","message":"and it is reused for every invocation of createAssignmentTable","date":"2016-06-25T03:49:38.869Z","type":"message"}
{"nick":"SwiftMatt","date":"2016-06-25T03:49:47.961Z","type":"join"}
{"nick":"deepestblue","date":"2016-06-25T03:50:05.046Z","type":"join"}
{"nick":"atombler","date":"2016-06-25T03:50:38.700Z","type":"join"}
{"nick":"joepie91","message":"essentially giving you the same benefits as you had before with subclasses, except this time 1) you don't have a bunch of implicit dependencies in the form of `this` properties - aside from `months`, all dependencies are completely explicit, meaning you can't accidentally break unrelated code, 2) you don't have the flexibility restrictions of classes, and 3) your code is no longer misleading","date":"2016-06-25T03:50:44.718Z","type":"message"}
{"nick":"pcfreak30","message":"is there a reason then everyone wants to use classes in es6","date":"2016-06-25T03:50:50.495Z","type":"message"}
{"nick":"pcfreak30","message":"is there a valid use case?","date":"2016-06-25T03:50:55.930Z","type":"message"}
{"nick":"joepie91","message":"pcfreak30: yes, there's a reason, two actually","date":"2016-06-25T03:51:03.988Z","type":"message"}
